articles.headline: Obama to Wall St.: ‘Join Us, Instead of Fighting Us’
articles.snippet: President Obama challenged some of the nation’s most influential bankers to embrace a new regulatory structure meant to avert another crisis.
articles.abstract: President Obama challenged some of the nation’s most influential bankers to embrace a new regulatory structure meant to avert another crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama took his rhetoric of reform on Thursday to the nation’s financial capital in a high-profile foray to chide Wall Street bankers for their “reckless practices” and to press for tighter regulations meant to avert another financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Documents Show Internal Qualms at Rating Agencies
articles.snippet: The agencies faced pressures from their clients, the same banks that were assembling and selling the investments, according to a Senate investigation.
articles.abstract: The agencies faced pressures from their clients, the same banks that were assembling and selling the investments, according to a Senate investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2004, well before the risks embedded in Wall Street’s bets on subprime mortgages became widely known, employees at Standard & Poor’s, the credit rating agency, were feeling pressure to expand the business.

articles.headline: U.S. Faces Choice on New Weapons for Fast Strikes
articles.snippet: The new weapons system is designed to hurl a conventional warhead of enormous weight at high speed and with pinpoint accuracy, without crossing the nuclear threshold.
articles.abstract: The new weapons system is designed to hurl a conventional warhead of enormous weight at high speed and with pinpoint accuracy, without crossing the nuclear threshold.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In coming years, President Obama will decide whether to deploy a new class of weapons capable of reaching any corner of the earth from the United States in under an hour and with such accuracy and force that they would greatly diminish America’s reliance on its nuclear arsenal.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Fortunate Timing Seals a Deal
articles.snippet: The suit filed against Goldman Sachs by the Securities and Exchange Commission helped sway opinion in favor of a regulatory overhaul of Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The suit filed against Goldman Sachs by the Securities and Exchange Commission helped sway opinion in favor of a regulatory overhaul of Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes there really are coincidences. Those who campaign for greater financial regulation have benefited from two of them over the last decade. In each case, the coincidence offset a lot of expensive lobbying.

articles.headline: For Web’s New Wave, Sharing Details Is the Point
articles.snippet: Web start-ups are pushing the boundaries of online sharing, asking people to post their most personal details.
articles.abstract: Web start-ups are pushing the boundaries of online sharing, asking people to post their most personal details.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Brooks wants the whole Web to know that he spent $41 on an iPad case at an Apple store, $24 eating at an Applebee’s, and $6,450 at a Florida plastic surgery clinic for nose work.

articles.headline: Deciding What Is ‘Suitable’ in Movie Ads
articles.snippet: Marilyn Gordon and the advertising review department evaluated more than 60,000 submissions last year.
articles.abstract: Marilyn Gordon and the advertising review department evaluated more than 60,000 submissions last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Most industries have invisible power players. In Hollywood, one of them is surely Marilyn Gordon.

articles.headline: A Setback for Greece as Europe Says Deficit Is Larger Than Thought
articles.snippet: Civil servants in Greece staged a strike as the European Union’s raised estimate of the country’s budget deficit sent borrowing costs higher.
articles.abstract: Civil servants in Greece staged a strike as the European Union’s raised estimate of the country’s budget deficit sent borrowing costs higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greece’s attempts to get its economy back on its feet and to regain investor trust suffered another setback Thursday as the European Union increased its estimate of the country’s 2009 budget deficit.

articles.headline: A Routine Deal Became an $840 Million Mistake
articles.snippet: Actions by some bankers suggested they were suspicious about the Abacus investment, which turned rickety.
articles.abstract: Actions by some bankers suggested they were suspicious about the Abacus investment, which turned rickety.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — To the bankers here, it seemed like a chance to make a quick $7 million — risk free.

articles.headline: Friend to Wall Street, Schumer Is Suddenly Quiet
articles.snippet: Senator Charles E. Schumer, known as an advocate for the financial industry, has kept a low profile in the regulation debate.
articles.abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer, known as an advocate for the financial industry, has kept a low profile in the regulation debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York has long been known as one of Wall Street’s best friends on Capitol Hill, but there are apparently limits to that friendship.

articles.headline: 2 Mines Show How Safety Practices Vary Widely
articles.snippet: A comparison between the safety practices of Massey Energy and those of other operators shows sharp differences.
articles.abstract: A comparison between the safety practices of Massey Energy and those of other operators shows sharp differences.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Dan Barry, Ian Urbina and Clifford Krauss.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Ian Urbina and Clifford Krauss
